ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned a lot of intermediate Arabic.
Better understanding of Arabic grammar and more conversational skills.
Knowledge of Arabic grammar and vocabulary, increased proficiency in reading, speaking, listening, and writing Arabic

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Incredible, amazing and engaging professor.

Weaknesses: Hard to learn a language over Zoom.
great strengths, next year will be on zoom which will be great
I think this course lost a lot by being online. I also would have liked to meet five days a week. But the small size and discussion format worked really well.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: cold calling was difficult, but good process overall
I liked section having discussions over Zoom. The one day of asynchronous work didn't help me learn much though, and I would have preferred a live Zoom seminar instead.

Having the lectures recorded and available outside of class was great, but having them available a bit earlier and a bit more of a constructive atmosphere when going over the grammar exercises would have been helpful

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. Do take this course to get a glimpse into the marvelous language of Arabic.
Yes! Arabic is an amazing language and Professor Elbousty is a really great teacher and person. I enjoyed almost all the time I spent in this class and felt like I learned a lot.
If they are willing to commit to learning a  new language, Arabic is a beautiful language and I learned a lot through the intro sequence.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also had section once a week where we reviewed grammar lessons.
Recorded lectures with virtual seminar-style classes
